per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Jacques Derrida? Provide as many specific details and examples as possible (such as names of people, numbers, events, locations, dates, times, etc.)
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Jacques Derrida (born Jackie Élie Derrida; July 15, 1930 – October 9, 2004) was a highly influential French philosopher, best known as the originator of the philosophical method called **deconstruction**. He was born in **El Biar, Algeria**, into a **Sephardic Jewish family** that had lived in Algeria for centuries before its colonization by France. His early life was marked by experiences of racial discrimination; for example, he was expelled from one school due to a 7% quota on Jewish students and withdrew from another because of anti-Semitism.

Derrida moved to France at the age of 22 (in **1952**) and began his studies at the **École Normale Supérieure (ENS)** in Paris, where he focused on the phenomenology of **Edmund Husserl**. He taught at the **Sorbonne** from **1960 to 1964**, and then at the **École Normale Supérieure** from **1964 to 1983**. In **1983**, he was elected **Director of Studies** at the **École des Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales (EHESS)** in Paris, a position he held from **1984**.

Derrida was a co-founder of the **Collège international de philosophie (CIPH)** in Paris in **1983**, alongside **François Châtelet** and others. He served as its first director. The institution was created to foster philosophical research that could not be conducted within traditional academic structures.

He was also a visiting professor and lecturer at universities around the world. From **1986** until his death in **2004**, he was **Professor of the Humanities at the University of California, Irvine**. He received honorary doctorates from institutions such as the **University of Cambridge** and **Columbia University**.

Derrida’s philosophical work was deeply influenced by the linguistics of **Ferdinand de Saussure**, as well as the phenomenology of **Edmund Husserl** and **Martin Heidegger**. He became disillusioned with **structuralism** and **phenomenology**, the dominant philosophical movements of his time, and developed deconstruction as a critical approach to challenge the assumptions of Western philosophy, particularly its **logocentrism** (the belief in a central, stable meaning or truth).

He was associated with the avant-garde **Tel Quel** group of intellectual theorists in Paris. His work questioned the binary oppositions in Western thought (such as speech/writing, presence/absence, reason/emotion), arguing that these hierarchies are unstable and that meaning is always deferred.

Derrida published over **40 books** and hundreds of essays and public presentations. His writings have been translated into more than **20 languages**. Some of his most famous works include **"Of Grammatology"** (1967), **"Writing and Difference"** (1967), and **"Speech and Phenomena"** (1967).

He was the subject of two documentary films and collaborated on many avant-garde art projects. He gave frequent interviews in a variety of media.

Derrida’s international reputation grew significantly from **1968** onward. He did not defend his **thèse d’état** (the terminal research qualification in the French higher education system) until **1980** at the Sorbonne.

In **1981**, he helped found the **Jan Hus Association**, which provided aid to dissident intellectuals in **Czechoslovakia**. In **1982**, he gave a secret seminar in **Prague** under its auspices, after which he was detained and arrested on fraudulent charges of drug trafficking. He was released with the help of French President **François Mitterrand**. This incident, along with his earlier experiences with anti-Semitism in Algeria, deeply affected him and contributed to his status as an international academic celebrity.

Derrida died in **Paris, France**, on **October 9, 2004**, at the age of 74. His work continues to influence philosophy, literature, law, anthropology, historiography, applied linguistics, sociolinguistics, psychoanalysis, music, architecture, and political theory.

per_prompt_data.prompt: What is the goal of Project Implicit, an online research project on implicit social cognition? Provide as many specific details and examples as possible (such as names of people, numbers, events, locations, dates, times, etc.)
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
The goal of **Project Implicit** is to **educate the public about implicit social biases** and to provide a **“virtual laboratory” for collecting data on implicit social cognition via the internet**. It is an international, nonprofit research collaboration that advances scientific knowledge about unconscious thoughts and feelings that influence perception, judgment, and behavior[2][5][7].

Key specific details include:

- **Founding and Leadership:** Project Implicit was founded in **1998** by three scientists: **Dr. Tony Greenwald** (University of Washington), **Dr. Mahzarin Banaji** (Harvard University), and **Dr. Brian Nosek** (University of Virginia)[5][7][9].

- **Core Tool – The Implicit Association Test (IAT):** The project’s signature research tool is the **Implicit Association Test (IAT)**, which measures implicit attitudes people hold about social groups (e.g., race, gender, age, sexual orientation, nationality). The IAT works by assessing reaction times during categorization tasks to reveal unconscious associations[1][10][11].

- **Public Engagement and Education:** Visitors to the Project Implicit website can take various IATs and receive **personalized feedback** comparing their results to others, along with explanations about what the test measures and how to interpret results. This serves to educate people about the existence and nature of implicit biases while simultaneously teaching psychological research methods[1][6][7].

- **Data Collection and Research:** Since its launch in **September 1998**, over **6 million IATs** have been completed worldwide, with about **20,000 tests taken weekly**. The website has been translated into **16 languages** and attracts a diverse international audience[1][8][12].

- **Collaborations and Scope:** Project Implicit is a collaboration between researchers at institutions including Harvard University, University of Virginia, University of Washington, Ben-Gurion University, and University of Florida. It conducts multiple research projects related to implicit cognition, bias, health, and social attitudes[6][7].

- **Expansion:** In 2011, Project Implicit expanded to include **Project Implicit Health** (formerly Project Implicit Mental Health), led by Dr. Bethany Teachman (University of Virginia) and Dr. Matt Nock (Harvard University), focusing on implicit cognition in mental health contexts[7][9].

- **Mission Statement:** The mission is threefold: (1) develop and deliver methods to investigate implicit social cognition, (2) increase public awareness and understanding of implicit bias, and (3) advance psychological research in this field[8].

- **Educational and Consulting Services:** Beyond research, Project Implicit offers education sessions, workshops, and consulting on topics such as bias, diversity, inclusion, and leadership development[3][9].

In summary, Project Implicit aims to make implicit social cognition research accessible and educational for the public while providing a robust online platform for ongoing scientific data collection and discovery about hidden biases and their effects on behavior.

per_prompt_data.prompt: Who is Rudolf Virchow? Provide as many specific details and examples as possible (such as names of people, numbers, events, locations, dates, times, etc.)
per_prompt_data.side2_response:
Rudolf Ludwig Carl Virchow (October 13, 1821 – September 5, 1902) was a German physician, pathologist, anthropologist, biologist, writer, editor, and politician, widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in 19th-century medicine and science. He is known as the "father of modern pathology" and the founder of social medicine.

### Personal Details
- **Full Name:** Rudolf Ludwig Carl Virchow
- **Born:** October 13, 1821, in Schivelbein, Pomerania, Prussia (now Świdwin, Poland)
- **Died:** September 5, 1902, in Berlin, Germany

### Major Contributions to Medicine

#### Cellular Pathology
- Virchow is best known for founding the field of **cellular pathology**, which revolutionized medicine by establishing that diseases originate at the cellular level.
- His seminal work, *Cellular Pathology* (*Die Cellularpathologie in ihrer Begründung auf physiologische und pathologische Gewebelehre*), was published in 1858 as a collection of his lectures.
- He formulated the principle **"omnis cellula e cellula"** ("all cells come from cells"), which became a cornerstone of cell theory and modern biology.
- Virchow was the first to describe **leukemia** and linked it to abnormal cell function, laying the foundation for cellular pathology.

#### Clinical Discoveries
- In 1846, Virchow disproved the prevailing belief that **phlebitis** (inflammation of a vein) was the cause of most diseases. Instead, he demonstrated that **thrombosis** (blood clot formation) and **embolism** (detachment of a clot) were responsible for many pathological conditions.
- He introduced the terms **"thrombosis"** and **"embolus"** into medical terminology.
- Virchow discovered the life cycle of **Trichinella spiralis**, a parasitic worm found in pork, which led to the establishment of compulsory meat inspection in Germany.

### Public Health and Social Medicine

- In 1848, Virchow was sent to investigate an epidemic of **"hunger typhus"** (relapsing fever) in **Upper Silesia**, a Prussian province with a Polish minority. His report criticized the government's social policies and emphasized that social conditions were as important as medical factors in disease outbreaks.
- He is considered the founder of **social medicine**, advocating for improvements in living conditions, sanitation, and public health to prevent disease.
- Virchow designed and supervised the construction of Berlin's first modern **sewage-disposal system**, which became a model for other cities.
- He organized the ambulance service for the Prussian army and opened a nursing school at the Friedrichshain Hospital in Berlin.
- Virchow played a key role in establishing **meat inspection** laws in Germany, which significantly reduced the incidence of trichinosis.

### Political and Social Activism

- Virchow was a member of the **Berlin City Council** from 1859 until his death, where he focused on public health issues such as sewage disposal, hospital design, meat inspection, and school hygiene.
- He supervised the design of two major Berlin hospitals: **Friedrichshain** and **Moabit**.
- Virchow was a founding member of the **Progressive Party** in Germany and was involved in military and social reforms.
- He advocated for the rights of minorities and was a vocal critic of social injustice.

### Anthropology and Archaeology

- Virchow was a pioneer in German anthropology and archaeology.
- In 1865, he discovered **pile dwellings** in northern Germany.
- In 1870, he began excavating **hill forts** in Pomerania.
- He founded the **German Anthropological Society** in 1869 and the **Berlin Society for Anthropology, Ethnology, and Prehistory**, serving as its president until his death.
- He edited the *Zeitschrift für Ethnologie* ("Journal of Ethnology") for many years.
- Virchow accompanied **Heinrich Schliemann**, the discoverer of Troy, to Troy in 1879 and to Egypt in 1888. He played a crucial role in ensuring that Schliemann's collection was donated to Berlin.
- He made personal expeditions to the **Caucasus** in 1881 and 1894.

### Legacy and Honors

- Virchow received the **Copley Medal** from the Royal Society in 1892, one of the highest scientific honors of the time.
